item.title: Coronavirus: Setback for EU in legal fight with AstraZeneca
item.description: But the drug-maker faces hefty fines if it fails to supply doses of Covid-19 vaccine over the summer.

item.title: UK Covid infections rise as Delta variant dominates
item.description: There is some regional variation in infection rates and some good news on vaccine efficacy.

item.title: Imran Ahmad Khan: Wakefield MP charged with sex assault on boy
item.description: The MP denies the offence, which is alleged to have happened in 2008.

item.title: Covid: UK cases continue to rise and Lloyd Webber rejects PM's offer
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Friday evening.

item.title: Crocodile attack: 'I was beating on its snout'
item.description: Georgia Laurie speaks to the BBC about how she fought off the crocodile attacking her twin sister.

item.title: Chesham and Amersham: Lib Dems overturn big Tory majority in by-election upset
item.description: Leader Ed Davey says his party is now the main threat to Tory "blue wall" constituencies across the UK.

item.title: 'I was told I didnâ€™t look like somebody who'd been raped'
item.description: One woman speaks to the BBC about her experience of reporting sexual assault.

item.title: Portland riots: Police crowd-control team resigns after officer indicted
item.description: The officer in the Portland crowd-control team faces an assault charge after last year's race riots.

item.title: Greece killing: Husband confesses to Caroline Crouch death
item.description: Police say a Greek pilot has admitted suffocating his wife in a crime that shocked the country.

item.title: Bloomsbury staff must be vaccinated before office return
item.description: The Harry Potter publisher will require all staff to be vaccinated before they return to offices.

item.title: Christian Eriksen: Denmark midfielder discharged from hospital
item.description: Christian Eriksen is discharged from hospital after a "successful" operation to fit a heart-starting device.

item.title: Andrew Lloyd Webber rejects PM's offer for Cinderella to be Covid pilot
item.description: The impresario had said he'd be willing to be arrested if Cinderella couldn't open to a full house.

item.title: Euro 2020: Christian Eriksen portrait made with Rubik's cubes
item.description: David Wright uses 500 of the colourful 3D puzzlers to create a likeness of the Danish footballer.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Why did EU take AstraZeneca to court?
item.description: The EU has lost a legal battle over its attempt to force AstraZeneca to deliver more vaccines to the bloc.

item.title: Chesham and Amersham by-election: Constituents react to result
item.description: Chesham and Amersham constituents share their thoughts on the Lib Dem victory.

item.title: Foo Fighters to release disco album as the Dee Gees
item.description: Dave Grohl's band rename themselves the Dee Gees and cover five 1970s hits by the Gibb brothers.

item.title: 'Ollerton 11' escapee pig family saved from slaughter
item.description: The sow, named Matilda, escaped from a farm and gave birth in woodland.

item.title: Man from Windsor to have 'record-breaking' kidneys removed
item.description: Warren Higgs says doctors believe he might have the heaviest kidneys in the world.

item.title: Why US millennials are quitting big cities
item.description: Remote workers are freer than ever to relocate, especially when smaller cities dangle incentives.

item.title: The Gurkha veterans fighting for Covid care in Nepal
item.description: Gurkhas living in a remote part of Nepal say they're struggling to access life-saving treatment for coronavirus.

item.title: How market research reveals what you really think
item.description: By sifting and analysing huge amounts of data, market researchers say they can find out what's on your mind.

item.title: Why the twins who had everything 'fell apart'
item.description: Sam and Chris Gould died four months apart, leaving their parents asking what could have saved them.

item.title: Download: 'Weird to get back to normality' for festival goers
item.description: Enter Shikari, and festival ticket holders talk about this weekend's 10,000 people event.

item.title: Once the future, US now captive to its past
item.description: History is inescapable to Americans and visitors alike but now it's become more contested than ever.

item.title: Edwin Poots' short legacy will 'help his successor'
item.description: Legislating for the Irish language is out of the hands of the next DUP leader, but challenges remain.

item.title: Juneteenth: What is the newest US holiday and how is it celebrated?
item.description: The commemoration of the last enslaved black American being freed is now an official US holiday.

item.title: In The Heights: What to know about the Lin-Manuel Miranda film
item.description: Lin-Manuel Miranda's movie musical has enjoyed positive reviews but also sparked a colourism row.

item.title: Are Asia's Covid 'winners' entering shaky new territory?
item.description: The places that were best at keeping Covid at bay are now struggling with their exit strategies.

item.title: Ethiopia election: A sham or democratic rebirth?
item.description: Why the stakes are so high in the nation's first attempt at free and fair elections.

item.title: Kenneth Kaunda: Zambia's independence hero
item.description: The first president of an independent Zambia, who became one of Africa's elder statesmen, dies at 97.

item.title: Euro 2020: Thousands of Scotland fans gather in central London
item.description: Large crowds of Tartan Army supporters congregate to watch the Euro 2020 match against England.

item.title: Euro 2020: 'Sing when no one's winning' - Micah Richards and Ashley Williams' half-time karaoke session
item.description: Watch Match of the Day pundits Ashley Williams and Micah Richards show off their vocal talents during the half-time analysis of a fairly uninspiring Sweden v Slovakia match.

item.title: England v India highlights: Hosts on top after day three in one-off Bristol Test
item.description: Watch highlights as England force the follow-on and put pressure on India, before rain halts their challenge for victory in the one-off Test at The Bristol County Ground.

item.title: Euro 2020: 'Ivan Perisic with a real piece of quality' - Croatia equalise with Perisic strike
item.description: Ivan Perisic cuts in from the left and strikes the ball across the keeper to bring Croatia back level against Czech Republic in the Euro 2020 group stage.

item.title: England on top against India in one-off Test despite rain
item.description: England put themselves in a strong position in the one-off Test against India despite much of the afternoon session being wiped out by rain.

item.title: Euro 2020: England v Scotland - rate the players
item.description: Rate the players in the Euro 2020 Group D match between England and Scotland.

item.title: England v Scotland: The fans who lost their Euro 2020 tickets
item.description: Some fans are having to make new plans after their tickets were cancelled.

item.title: Euro 2020: Scotland v England at Euro 1996 and what life was like then
item.description: As the Euro 2020 game looms, what was life like last time the rivals met in a major tournament?

item.title: Yes Sir, I Can Boogie: Why disco hit is now Scotland's unofficial anthem
item.description: The 1970s disco classic has become the country's unofficial anthem ahead of the match with England.

item.title: Euro 2020 and Covid: How can I watch with my friends?
item.description: Covid rules are making things a bit different for Euro 2020 spectators.

item.title: Euro 2020: Who will England's 'little Scotland' be supporting?
item.description: Corby often celebrates its Scottish heritage, but when it comes to football who will the town back?

item.title: Euro 2020: England journalists on history of England-Scotland rivalry
item.description: England journalists discuss the age-old footballing rivalry between England and Scotland, while Kelly Somers catches up with Jordan Pickford before the big Group D game on Friday.

item.title: England 2-0 Scotland: What was it like to be on the receiving end of Paul Gascoigne's genius?
item.description: Paul Gascoigne's brilliant Euro 96 goal is one of English football's most famous moments but it meant a defeat at Wembley which is still hard to swallow for Scotland.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over 40s in England and Scotland can have their second dose after eight weeks instead of 12.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Coronavirus restrictions are staying in place because of concerns about the Delta variant.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 42 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Covid: What do over-18s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now available for younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go... and who with?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: Coronavirus G7: Could a billion more vaccines for poorer countries make a difference?
item.description: How much difference could the G7 offer of a billion vaccines make to tackling the pandemic?

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: What are the rules for pubs, restaurants, festivals and gigs?
item.description: The lifting of restrictions is being delayed, which could affect planned events

item.title: What are the social distancing rules and when could they end?
item.description: Will we still need to be socially distanced through the summer? A social distancing review is advising the government.

item.title: Covid: Is there a limit to how much worse variants can get?
item.description: The coronavirus has changed and changed again, getting more transmissible each time.

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself from Covid now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Lockdown easing: Four numbers to look for ahead of the 21 June decision
item.description: The key numbers that offer clues as to whether "freedom day" will proceed as planned on 21 June.
